verses.text: There was a long war between the house of Saul and the house of David. David grew stronger and stronger, while the house of Saul grew weaker and weaker.
verses.comment: Reflects original's contrast of power between David and Saul's houses.

verses.text: And sons were born to David at Hebron: his firstborn was Amnon, by Ahinoam of Jezreel;
verses.comment: Maintains the ordering and mother's names as in Hebrew text.

verses.text: His second, Chileab, by Abigail the widow of Nabal of Carmel; and the third, Absalom the son of Maacah, daughter of Talmai king of Geshur;
verses.comment: Chileab is called Daniel in 1 Chr. 3:1; name retained from 2 Samuel.

verses.text: The fourth, Adonijah son of Haggith; the fifth, Shephatiah son of Abital;
verses.comment: Names and order follow Hebrew text.

verses.text: And the sixth, Ithream, by Eglah, David's wife. These were born to David in Hebron.
verses.comment: Lists David’s wives and sons at Hebron.

verses.text: While there was war between the house of Saul and the house of David, Abner was strengthening his position in the house of Saul.
verses.comment: Emphasizes Abner's growing influence.

verses.text: Saul had a concubine named Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah. And Ish-bosheth said to Abner, "Why have you gone in to my father's concubine?"
verses.comment: Ancient concerns over royal succession and concubines.

verses.text: Abner was very angry at the words of Ish-bosheth and said, "Am I a dog's head from Judah? Today I show kindness to your father's house, to his brothers and friends, and have not delivered you into David's hand; yet you charge me today with a crime concerning this woman."
verses.comment: "Dog's head" is an insult; retained literal phrase from Hebrew.

verses.text: May God do so to Abner and more also, if I do not do for David as Yahweh has sworn to him,
verses.comment: Uses covenant oath formula, as in the original.

verses.text: To transfer the kingdom from the house of Saul and set up the throne of David over Israel and Judah, from Dan even to Beersheba."
verses.comment: "Dan to Beersheba" marks all Israel; preserved original phrasing.

verses.text: And Ish-bosheth could not answer Abner another word, because he feared him.
verses.comment: Maintains narrative of Abner's dominance.

verses.text: Abner sent messengers to David at Hebron, saying, "To whom does the land belong? Make your covenant with me, and my hand will be with you to bring all Israel over to you."
verses.comment: "To whom does the land belong?" preserves ambiguity of Hebrew.

verses.text: He said, "Good; I will make a covenant with you. But one thing I require of you: You shall not see my face unless you bring Michal, Saul's daughter, when you come to see me."
verses.comment: David's demand for Michal preserved as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: And David sent messengers to Ish-bosheth, Saul's son, saying, "Give me my wife Michal, whom I became engaged to with a hundred Philistine foreskins."
verses.comment: Literal number and context preserved.

verses.text: So Ish-bosheth sent and took her from her husband Paltiel the son of Laish.
verses.comment: The forced transfer is retained.

verses.text: But her husband went with her, weeping as he followed her to Bahurim. Then Abner said to him, "Go, return." So he returned.
verses.comment: "Weeping" emphasizes the tragic separation as in original.

verses.text: Abner conferred with the elders of Israel and said, "For some time you have wanted David to be your king.
verses.comment: Abner acts as political broker, as in original.

verses.text: "Now then, do it! For Yahweh has spoken concerning David: 'By the hand of my servant David I will save my people Israel from the hand of the Philistines and from the hand of all their enemies.'"
verses.comment: Direct quote; rendered as prophecy.

verses.text: Abner also spoke in the hearing of Benjamin. Then Abner went to speak to David at Hebron about all that seemed good to Israel and the whole house of Benjamin.
verses.comment: Shows effort to gain widespread support.

verses.text: Abner came to David at Hebron, accompanied by twenty men. David made a feast for Abner and the men who were with him.
verses.comment: Hospitality signified covenant making.

verses.text: Abner said to David, "I will arise and go and gather all Israel to my lord the king, so that they may make a covenant with you, and you may reign over all that your heart desires." David sent Abner away, and he went in peace.
verses.comment: Abner calls David "my lord the king", as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Just then, David’s servants and Joab returned from a raid, bringing much spoil with them. But Abner was no longer with David in Hebron, for David had sent him away, and he had gone in peace.
verses.comment: Joab’s arrival timed after Abner’s departure.

verses.text: When Joab and all the army that was with him arrived, Joab was told, "Abner the son of Ner came to the king, and he has sent him away, and he has gone in peace."
verses.comment: Reported speech matches original’s narrative.

verses.text: Then Joab went in to the king and said, "What have you done? Abner came to you! Why did you send him away, so he is gone?
verses.comment: Joab’s challenge rendered as direct questioning.

verses.text: You know that Abner son of Ner came to deceive you, to learn your going out and your coming in, and to know everything you do."
verses.comment: "To learn your going out and coming in" is idiomatic and retained as such.

verses.text: When Joab left David, he sent messengers after Abner, and they brought him back from the cistern of Sirah, but David did not know about it.
verses.comment: "Cistern of Sirah" is the traditional location, as in Hebrew.

verses.text: When Abner returned to Hebron, Joab took him aside into the gateway to speak with him privately, and there he struck him in the stomach and killed him, avenging the blood of Asahel his brother.
verses.comment: Narrates the murder as retribution, as in original.

verses.text: When David heard about it, he said, "I and my kingdom are innocent before Yahweh forever of the blood of Abner the son of Ner.
verses.comment: David's exoneration formula retained.

verses.text: "Let it fall on the head of Joab and on all his father's house. Let there never be one lacking who has a discharge or is leprous, or holds a spindle, or falls by the sword, or lacks bread."
verses.comment: Curse formula retains Hebrew terms; "holds a spindle" likely means crippled or weak.

verses.text: So Joab and Abishai his brother killed Abner because he had killed their brother Asahel at Gibeon in the battle.
verses.comment: Motivation for killing Abner explained as in original.

verses.text: David said to Joab and to all the people with him, "Tear your clothes, put on sackcloth, and mourn before Abner." And King David himself walked behind the bier.
verses.comment: Funeral rites detailed as in original Hebrew culture.

verses.text: They buried Abner in Hebron. And the king wept aloud at Abner's tomb, and all the people wept.
verses.comment: Public mourning stressed as in original.

verses.text: And the king lamented over Abner and said: "Should Abner die as a fool dies?
verses.comment: David’s lament begins; "as a fool dies" retained original idiom.

verses.text: "Your hands were not bound, your feet were not put in chains; as one falls before the wicked, so you have fallen." And all the people wept over him again.
verses.comment: Poetic lament rendered closely to Hebrew parallelism.

verses.text: Then all the people came to persuade David to eat food while it was still day, but David swore, saying, "May God do so to me and more also, if I taste bread or anything else until the sun sets!"
verses.comment: David’s oath of mourning matches original formula.

verses.text: All the people took note, and it pleased them. Just as everything the king did pleased all the people.
verses.comment: Reflects David’s popularity, as in original narrative.

verses.text: So all the people and all Israel understood that day that it was not from the king to kill Abner son of Ner.
verses.comment: David's innocence in Abner's death affirmed.

verses.text: The king said to his servants, "Do you not know that a prince and a great man has fallen this day in Israel?
verses.comment: David honors Abner’s rank with royal language.

verses.text: And today, though I am anointed king, I am weak, and these men, the sons of Zeruiah, are too harsh for me. May Yahweh repay the evildoer according to his evil."
verses.comment: David expresses political vulnerability; "sons of Zeruiah" reference retained.
